Joel Halbert wrote:
> Thanks for the feedback. 
> 
> Our main goals are:
> 
> 1. achieving maximum use of commodity hardware. If we want to distribute
> 200k domains across say, 4 machines, we would like to ensure that if one
> machine has already processed 50k domains (because they were smaller
> sites) then we can keep loading up more domains for it to process to
> take up the slack. 

This goal (considered alone) is best served by a large crawl with all
seeds entered at the very start. Then the only things limiting the
crawler will be thread availability, IO throughput, and the politeness
settings. (As long as there are URIs pending and eligible, it will try
them ASAP.)

A number of the 'cost' or 'budget' related settings affect how Heritrix
rotates thread attention among queues with pending URIs. I've put some
notes about these settings on the project wiki here:

http://webarchive.jira.com/wiki/display/Heritrix/Frontier+queue+budgets

> From the docs I gather you can edit a seed list for a running job. Can
> you add to the seed list programatically? Can we see which seeds
> (domains) in the seed list have completed their crawl - can this be
> determined, as you suggested, from the job summary and frontier
> reports? 

Whenever you can avoid it, you'd rather not change the seeds/scope 
during a crawl. It can make coverage dependent on arbitrary 
order-of-discovery/change differences.

For example, let's say you want to crawl site A. One of the pages on A 
includes the root page of site B in an IFrame, so that one page (but not 
all of site B) is crawled by inline inclusion. Some time later, you add 
to that same crawl the root page of B, and expand the crawl's scope to 
include site B. However, since the crawl already visited root-B, it 
won't be revisited. And because when it was visited, the rest of site B 
wasn't in-scope, it may not be discovered and crawled.

So while you *can* add seeds, and adjust scope, during a crawl, in 
general you want to do that to adjust for things that couldn't have been 
foreseen, rather than as a matter of course.

Some notes on how to add URIs mid-crawl are now at:

http://webarchive.jira.com/wiki/display/Heritrix/Adding+URIs+mid-crawl

You can deduce if a host-centric queue is still in progress from the 
'frontier report'. When viewed in the Web UI, only a manageably-sized 
excerpt of this report is shown (so it might be missing info on some 
queues of interest). However, when you use the UI's link to 'Force 
generation of end-of-crawl Reports', you get full reports, and the 
frontier report is in a more compact format with one line per 
nonempty-queue.  (Generating these reports can be time-consuming in a 
large crawl.)

If a queue did have URIs, but is now empty, then in some sense that host 
is 'finished'. Of course, more previously-unknown material could be 
discovered via other paths. Whether the heuristic "we've crawled the 
root page, and everything reachable from it, and now the queue is empty" 
is a good enough definition of "completed" depends on your project.

> 2. Detailed reporting for each domain e.g. number of pages discovered,
> pending, queued, errors etc...  You suggested we might be able to gather
> this information by creating alternate views on the jobs in process from
> the existing logs & reports? Can we hook into these reports
> programatically or would it require us to process the log files?

The forced-dump of reports mid-crawl might be enough for you; it 
includes host-centric reports and the aforementioned frontier-report 
that might be plenty of info for you.

We don't use the forced-dumps very often in our operations, and 
generating the full reports on a large, in-process crawl is 
time-consuming and memory-stressing. So, if you were doing it many times 
per day in an unpaused crawl, there could be problems. (Or maybe not; 
testing is suggested.) But doing in once per day in a temporarily paused 
crawl should be safe.

And, if all else fails, generating reports from the crawl.log isn't too 
hard. It won't include pending URI counts -- but those are in the 
frontier report, or could even be deduced by crunching the recovery.gz log.

> 3. Importantly, we need to be able to use specific crawl scopes for each
> domain. Some may be DomainScope, others PathScope. How easy is it to
> construct the appropriate scopes for multiple domains in a single job?

It's possible via the per-domain-overrides mechanism, but not 
super-easy, and might get unwieldy if you have many thousands of 
different scopes (as opposed to specializations for a few big/important 
sites).

We don't recommend either DomainScope or PathScope for current crawls; 
the bundled default DecidingScope with a SurtPrefixedDecideRule (and 
whatever other edits you need) is more efficient and offers 
functionality that is a superset of both those older scopes.

For example, it may be all the specific scoping you need -- for example 
you can have it do A.COM and all its subdomains; B.COM exactly without 
subdomains, and C.COM/SUBPATH/ without getting other areas of C.COM. The 
key idea is to rearrange URIs into what we call 'SURT form', where the 
domain-name-segments also become more specific left-to-right like 
path-segments, and then turns most scoping decisions into shared-prefix 
comparisons.

If you do wind up needing to use per-domain overrides, a tactic to keep 
in mind is that overriding is easiest when either enabling/disabling 
components, or changing primitive values. So if you think you'll need a 
special scope rule for some domains, it's best to add to the global 
settings, but mark it disabled -- then override the 'enabled' flag on 
target domains. Or, include a rule for blocking URIs by regular 
expression which is empty for the global settings -- but is overridden 
with domain-specific blocks for certain domains.

> We would like to "work with the framework" in achieving our goals,
> rather than fitting a square peg into a round hole, so hopefully  the
> above is do-able using Heritrix best practice!

Hope this helps!

- Gordon @ IA

> At the Internet Archive, we don't usually split up crawls to 
> one-site-per-job. We prefer fewer jobs, with more seeds/sites. We then 
> rely on postprocessing and indexing to extract individual sites, or
> site 
> statistics, later.
> 
> Some other groups do a job-per-site, with Heritrix, but it's not very 
> easy to run many jobs simultaneously in the same running instance.
> (It's 
> possible, but a little tricky -- unless you shrink some of the usual
> job 
> parameters, most importantly in 1.14.x the bdb-cache percentage, 
> simultaneous jobs can exhaust all allocated JVM memory. And I think 
> those who have done so have done more like dozens per instance, rather 
> than hundreds.)
> 
> Some potential weaknesses of the one-job-per-site approach:
> 
> - offsite inline resources, which our default configuration gets 
> (because we want as accurate a rendition of the page as possible), may 
> be duplicated between the jobs -- each has no idea another may have 
> already retrieved that URI
> 
> - if there are 'deep' areas of a site only discoverable from other 
> sites, but not from the home site's root page, these may not be 
> collected in separate crawls. (In the job they're discovered, they're 
> out-of-scope; in the job for their own site, they're not discovered.)
> 
> - because of trying to schedule/distribute the jobs, within the 
> constraints of a certain amount of per-job overhead, hardware may often 
> be underutilized
> 
> Unless the sites are especially large, a single job on a single
> powerful 
> machine may be plenty to collect 200K sites. A crawler with (for 
> example) 200 crawling 'toe' threads is actually making maximal progress 
> on far more than 200 sites at once, because while some sites are in 
> 'politeness wait', threads continue on other sites with pending URIs. 
> And since many sites are not large, many crawls finish most of their 
> target sites in the first hours/days of crawling, with later days/weeks 
> only working on the very deep or very slow sites.
> 
> What are your main goals in splitting the jobs up?
> 
> Can those goals be met by postprocessing, or by creating alternate
> views 
> of a single in-progress job's logs and reports? (For example, you can 
> force dump larger per-host-summary and frontier-queue reports from a 
> running crawl.)
> 
> - Gordon @ IA
>
